What if Carma - the person - is a modified skin. You've heard rumors that while a skin, things can be done to it and then return the person without them knowing. What if it is a self-sealing skin that you can't escape?

Damn! I should have checked the opening to see if it was normal, you think starting to panic. That was barely mentioned in class, but you were too preoccupied with Nancy and Carma that you forgot.

You look around and wonder if you can get off somewhere and try it. There is a restroom just for this room, and one of the bridesmaids is on her way there. If you're stuck, maybe you don't want to go through with the plan. Or maybe you will be released if you make it back as Carma and still maintain secrecy. Or maybe you should switch, again, if you can.

A knock sounds at the door. That should be the delivery of the Scarlet Bloom. Carma's desire for it forces your eyes to lock onto the door. She wants to be near it so bad that your crotch is starting to moisten. Should you trust the organization, they must have tested the pen and wouldn't do something like this to you ... would they?
11221221121212212122212111.title: Keep it up as Carma

112212211212122121222121111.content:
You watch the bitch down another champagne and smile. Not a smirk, or a grin of malicious, calculated evil. A serene, pleasant smile of false delight. You're so comfortable pretending to support Alexandra; you have been since you grew apart at college. You think of the end game, of Holden's grasp around your body, and feel your muscles tense with desire. Not long to go now.

You were worried about something in the waiting room an hour ago, although what has slipped from your mind. Something to do with... pens, maybe? It's hard to recall. And hardly relevant. You've been slowly increasing the pressure on Alexandra since the room, adding to her neuroses, planting doubts in her mind.

Can you walk in heels and a wedding dress? Oh, don't forget your words, honey. Yes, dear, you stand over... whoops, how awful, you've fallen in the mud. Better get that white dress cleaned up or you'll look a state, won't you?

Years of revenge. All coming to fruition tonight. It's like the poem. And I sunnied it with smiles, and with soft, deceitful wiles...

You take a slow sip of the champagne, letting the fizz rush up your nose. It's almost time for the speeches, and the cake cutting, and that first, fateful dance. You glance over to Alexandra again, watching the haze in her eyes, wondering if she'll dance straight. The Scarlet Bloom sparkles as it sways with its owners tipsy motion.

Perfect, you grin. You rise, and slip over, running a fingernail briefly across Holden's neck as you pass him, to slip down next to Alexandra.

"How are we doing, Mrs Parry?" You say, so sweet and innocent, listening for a tell-tale slur. Alexandra answers with a "Wonderful, Carms", her words already drawn out: a combination of the pills and the alcohol. You grin, and step out of the marquee for fresh air. A faint memory tells you that the garden path will be a nice, isolated spot. You don't know why you think that, but you decide to take a walk there. The air is pleasant, the scent of the flowers sweet... and perhaps there's a little whiff of pot in the air, too. Maybe someone has snuck out of the reception. You turn down the path, walking round the side of the summer house, and lean up against it, laughing.

You can't resist the urge any longer. You need to slip this masquerade and grin at how perfectly the plan is going. You slip your hand into your clutch, absent-mindedly checking your cell messages while you wait for everything to unfold in the marquee. There's a strange pen inside, and you wonder where you picked it up. Why would you, Carma Hamilton, have a strange pen? Maybe you'll throw it away after the reception. You pick up the cell, and...

Oh my God! I've got snot coming out of my nose!

You turn on the camera, pointing it at yourself. Sure enough, there's a faint green trickle of slime, spilling out. Like a green suit.

What's a green suit?

A green pen... the pens. The PENS!

Without another thought of Carma's, you suddenly realize the grave danger you're in. You grab the pen and hit the white switch, cutting away Carma's beautiful head, freeing your Kurt skin. It's covered in green slime. You begin to wipe it away, scraping it off your face, wiping it against the wall you're leaning against.

Shit. A green pen means a suit that can convince its wearer they really were that person. You suddenly realize you haven't been pretending to be Carma Hamilton for the past hour; you've actually thought you were her. You need to change out of this skin and into another one, and quickly.

The problem is, you're now trapped. The reception is going on, and you're stuck in a garden, the body of Carma Hamilton, her head and perfect hair clasped in your hands. There's also no sign of anyone you could swap into quickly, let alone use to get back to the Bloom. This area is off limits, you put the order in yourself. Your only hope is that some guest decided to ignore the 'no entry' sign and sneak off from the reception for a short while, or that one of the staff is nearby, through one of the hedgerows. Either way, you've got to get out of Carma quickly - and back to steal the Bloom.

You panic and wonder what you're going to do.
112212211212122121222121111.title: Out of Control

choices: It works, and you break the spell.
When you awake, Alexandra and the Scarlet Bloom are gone.
1122122112121221212221211112.content:
There's a noise on the other side of the hedge, so you slide down the path looking for an opening to see who, or what, it may be. Cigarette smoke drifts up your nostrils. It must be someone sneaking a forbidden pleasure as the entire resort and all its grounds are smoke-free. Two more steps, and you can make out a small figure, nondescript in the dark. Then a red glow illuminates the face causing you to smile. No one else is around.

The pen fires on instinct, and you zip around the hedge pulling off the Carma suit as you go. Within a couple seconds, you're there and quickly stomp the butt before it can do any damage. There's no way to know how much time you have, so you reseal Carma tossing her back around the hedge. The slime quickly dries and falls off like powder as you brush yourself. Fortunately it only works when in the suit, so you step into your new skin then pull the person's clothes on.

In training, you held the second fastest record for switching out of one suit and into another including clothing. It took you a while to master the complexity of women's garments, but now those aere almost as easy as stepping into a skin. That is good, because you hear footsteps coming down the path where Carma is. Carma should be waking up about now, but that's no longer your concern as you hustle back to the reception.

When you step into the the tiki torch and moon lit garden, Alexandraias dancing in her bare feet like a fairy under a spell. Everyone seems spellbound with eyes upon her. You ignore her and gatherd up the used glasses and abandoned cake plates setting them on the trays to go back to the kitchen. The flute and percussion music tease your ears as you wander and wonder about the hypnotized crowd.

Unholy crap! you suddenly think as you realize it is a fairy spell or, at least, a high tech version. You remember this discussion in training, and that it is very dangerous for anyone in or out of a suit.

No one is moving except Alexandra. Your eyes keep drifting toward the florescent figure in the center of the ring, and you have to force them back to avoid being trapped as well. If you look at her for more than a few seconds, all hope will be lost, and you will become rooted to the ground thinking aimless thoughts and completely paralyzed.

This is not part of Carma's plan, so someone else must be after the Scarlet Bloom, someone or organization that has the knowledge and capability to invoke such things. Having almost been trapped in a greener as the green slime suits are called, you consider if it is your organization again. The shield glasses you need are in Kurt's bag back in the hotel. For an instant, you consider trying to get them, but that would take too much time. Your only hope is to maintain your willpower and see what happens, but your body has already turned toward Alexandra, and something invisible is pulling your chin up and twisting your neck to face her as well. You can't even make your eyes close any more.

It must be the music. The only way to save yourself is to plug your ears and scream.
1122122112121221212221211112.title: Grab a staff member

11221221121212212122212111121.content:
You do the only thing you can do. You plug your ears and scream. The music haunts you, lingers across your mind in a drifting melody that makes you want to do little more than gaze out into the crowd and watch Alexandra's strange pirouettes and arcs, but you plug your ears, only increasing the volume of the scream. Your false voice resounds through the tent, its pitch barely loud enough to prevent the strange chimes from touching your brain. It feels like you're fighting against an invisible fog, cutting through a misty veil that has enraptured everyone else.

And all the while, Alexandra Parry dances as if she'll never stop, entranced.

You stagger from table to table, knocking over plates and bumping into people, but nobody seems to even notice, so caught up are they in the strange dance. This is high tech stuff, you realize. Some would call it magic, but Gunther used to talk about the different permutations and possibilities of acoustic weaponry. Such a thought, he used to say, was as old as time itself. The Greeks knew it as a siren: the haunting melody making people oblivious to the calamity.

You continue screaming. Screaming until your jaw aches. Screaming as you force your way toward your only salvation. Whoever is doing this must have 'made' you now, but you're sure you've spotted them, too: an ear plug in the crowd. It's too hard to concentrate on who it was at the moment, though. You just continue to force your way past mesmerized guests, toward...

You stumble and fall, just short of your goal. Your ears are uncovered, and the entrancing music fills your head again. Mechanically, your head begins to turn toward Alexandra, even from your prone position. You can't fight it this time. All you can do is reach out with your hands, fumbling, grasping, tugging...

The music stops. You turn, shocked to see you managed to do it. You've pulled out the plug socket. Everyone stands for a moment, unsure what they were doing. Carma staggers back into the party, none the worse for - literally - wear, and Alexandra finishes her dance and looks utterly bemused. Amid the confused faces you recognize at least one frustrated scowl. You stagger to your feet, walk to the music deck, and retrieve the CD. Seconds later you smash it in your palm, and rush out of the room.

The Carma suit wasn't the organization's doing. The room switch, the way down... it was a trap. A trap you fell for, and managed to get out of. Someone else is here, playing a high stakes game with you. They want the Bloom too, and now they know who you are. You're pretty sure you've identified them, but that doesn't mean they won't switch identities too. Behind you, guests are clapping Alexandra's 'performance' - although you doubt they realize what they are clapping. Other guests are talking about entertainment, even more are heading to the resort's toilets. The sun has set, and it's dark in the surrounds.

You've got a few options. Grabbing another disguise seems to make sense - you're recognized and if you're going to get the Bloom you'll have to go unnoticed, both by the guests and your rivals. That will be hard - especially given how everyone in this crazy wedding seems to be up to something. Alternatively, you could move against your rivals. They might have all the advantages, but you have a few tricks up your sleeve too. As a worst case scenario you could wait for things to play out, and either retrieve the Bloom from Carma's scheme, or obtain it from Alexandra as she and Holden head to their suite later.
11221221121212212122212111121.title: Soul Music

choices: Try for Rodney or some guest.
112212211212122121222121111211.content:
You head back to the kitchen with a tray of dirty dishes knowing you need to switch. You're amazed how strong the slim woman is that you suited. Obviously, she works out which her memories confirm. She's even allowed to use the resort's facilities as a perk of the job. She was there earlier before her shift. You must have just missed her. She's also a health food addict. It seems a strange combination that she was off smoking when you suited her, but you have other things to think about besides analyzing her. At least there's nothing to indicate she was tampered with by your organization.

"Hey, Suzy. How's the party going?" It's Rob Johnson, a good friend of Suzy's. Tall and lean and platonic, though Suzy would gladly do him, but even her flirts have never drawn any interest. He's a dishwasher at the resort. Doesn't smoke and enjoys the good food of life: sugary and greasy.

"Weird and wild like they all are. Fortunately, no one has climbed on the tables like last week."

"Wish I could have seen that one. Not much fun just cleaning up all night after the rich, but it pays the bills."

"Yeah. Got another couple hours before we have to clear everything, but Rodney said we may have to stay later, after midnight. Don't mind the extra pay, though." Rob smiles and nods concurrence.

Rodney's the kitchen and bar manager. He's an ass that gets to strut around and give orders if he thinks anything isn't going right. He was one of the people with ear-phones during Alexandra's dance. Supposedly, they're connected to his walkie-talkie so he can use to call the kitchen or security.

As if on cue, a blast comes through the kitchen speakers. "Suzy, where have you gotten to? You better not be off smoking somewhere. There's glasses and plates piling up, and bring out some clean ones. They're using 'em up fast. Rob better have the first batch washed by now."

You and Rob share a shake of your heads and both mouth, "Asshole."

As you carry back the tray of clean dishes, you think of how best it would be to get to the Bloom. As a service person, your chances of getting anywhere near Alexandra are slim. Maybe you could suit Rodney; he has a much better chance, and you could find out from his memories if he's involved in the fairy snatch that you foiled.

It'd be better if you could get back into the wedding party. However, Rodney will probably be watching you closely making it difficult to sneak off following someone who may go for a break to the restroom or just off down one of the paths. Plus whoever was using the Fairy dance tech is going to be watching you as well. Although, Rodney can't stop you if you have to use the restroom yourself as long as you're quick. "Don't just sit around peeing all night," as he's liable to say per Suzy's past encounters with him on the same subject. He's a stupid, insensitive ass.

Just as you round a bend behind the bushes, a guest approaches you. He's tall and moves nicely. You can tell he's well built the way he carries himself. With the light behind him, though, you can't make out the face. You could probably pen him and switch right here since no one should be using this path except the staff which is really just you until the servers are done.

"Excusse me, m-miths. Is thiths the w-way to the rrrrrresthtrooms?" His slurring indicates he's had quite a bit to drink, but that's not what draws your attention. You recognize the voice. It's Holden Perry, the groom.
112212211212122121222121111211.title: Service staff work

1122122112121221212221211112111.content:
You smile Suzy's most winning smile, the one she uses in the main restaurant to gather as many tips as she can.

"No, sir. It's down this way." You point, balancing the plates you are carrying, down a walk that leads further into the garden. This is a perfect opportunity; as the groom you can comfortably get closer to the Bloom, and nobody would ask any questions. Holden sways, and gives you a dreamy, sleepy smile, turning the direction you pointed and beginning to stagger his way down the path.

Quietly, you look for somewhere to set down the tray of plates and turn, Suzy's flat shoes - ideal for waitress work - crunching the soft gravel behind. Holden's staggering all over the path, and you step into the shadows of the hedgerows as you stalk him. You're too close to the main path at the moment, even if it's only used by service staff, and want to make sure you're not disturbed. Your opponents - whoever they are - know who they're looking for, and that means you've got to be doubly careful until you make your switch. Up ahead, Holden has paused, looking baffled by your directions. As he should be - you've just led him further out into the isolated gardens.

Then his face appears delighted.

"Ahhh, siiir. Issssth the way to the..." he never finishes his sentence. Suzy's pale blue eyes widen with shock as Holden Parry collapses into a suit in front of you. A shadow emerges from the square.

Rodney. So you were right. Without another thought, he begins to shed his clothes, then grappling over Rodney's head, pulling his black hair in front of his face, and sliding it off. The man looks young - early 20s at a guess - but with a weasel-like face and pock-marked cheeks. You don't recognize him, but then, in your line of work, that means practically nothing. Without hesitation, he begins to slip into Holden Parry's collapsed skin, tugging his legs over his own, grabbing the torso and forcing it up, slipping his hands into the arms and flexing his new fingers - still wearing the wedding ring. In seconds the head is drawn over his own, and a naked Holden stands there.

You crouch in the shadows, watching this unfold. You've caught your opponent - assuming he's the only one. There might be more; Rodney wasn't the only one with a headset, after all. And your worst feelings as confirmed as the new Holden, flexing his muscles as he does so, slips into the groom's trousers and shirt, buttoning up the cuffs, and slides into the jacket.

"Switched to Plan B. I'm now the groom. Repeat, I'm now the groom. Any sign of our unwanted guest? Last seen in a waitress, Suzanne Goldman. Yeah, well, find her. One sec... shit. This guy's memories say she was on the main path less than a minute ago. Everyone, get over here. Comb the grounds! Hold on..."

Holden, or whoever he is, turns to his pen set, and levels it at Rodney. A small green beam hits the still-deflated manager. "Just covering our tracks," he says, firing another pen to reinflate Rodney. "Right. Scout the place. I'm heading to the restrooms, you check the kitchens. She can't have gone far. Remember, Plan B. So hold fire until the honeymoon suite." Holden laughs. "I'm going to have some fun with this."

You keep crouched, watching as 'Holden' turns and walks down the path, eyes searching. You hold your breath as he storms past, looking out for you, and relax a little as he keeps going. Rodney is beginning to stir, but he's not an option: unless you're mistaken, he's been converted to a greener.

If you head to the left, you could quickly slip past Rodney and work your way around to the entertainers' preparation area. From there you could easily slip into either the main marquee, or grab one of the entertainment staff: a singer, the band, the magician or assistant. Nancy might even be around, coordinating things.

Alternatively, you could wait for whoever comes to hunt you down. You've got a pen set of your own after all; you could surprise whoever is tracking you and impersonate them. Maybe you could even get hold of a green pen. You know Gunther would love to get his hands on one of those, break it down and find out what it's made of. It would be even better than coming back with the Bloom.

You're certainly not going to let whoever your opposition are take this from you.
1122122112121221212221211112111.title: Hold Up

11221221121212212122212111121112.content:
You decide to take a big chance and get out of Suzy, seal her back up, and have her re-inflate. With luck, she'll just think she was daydreaming with a flashback/blackout from her days using those hallucinogens and not realize how much time has passed. Of course, that leaves you naked and afraid. There's all kinds of reasons that a naked man wandering around a wedding reception will draw attention, but you have no plans to wander around. Quickly you toss her with clothes still on over by the tray of dishes before the skin starts to inflate and sneak back into the darkness.

Figuring someone is bound to be by soon, your plan is to take one of them and go on the offensive from the inside. It's time to use your ability to blend into the scenery, or in this case, hide in the bushes. You recall how stupid the training session seemed as you were stripped naked and put into various suits and taken blindfolded into places where you should stand out. However, you found that you had an amazing natural ability to actually not be noticed. Of course, most of your life, you seemed to not be there. People would talk about you in front of you like you weren't there.

"You know he would look much better in a green shirt."

"I don't know why he continues to wear those ugly brown pants."

"It's like he's just trying to be difficult."

"Mom, Dad, I'm right here"

"That's nice, son. ... Do you think he even cares about his appearance, dear?"

Your thoughts are interrupted by a crunch of gravel and Suzy's voice coming from the darkness to your left.

"Let go of me, you creepy dirt bag. I'm not some floozy you rich bastards can drag into the bushes and ..."

It suddenly stops, and you can imagine why. One of the thugs must have found her and used a pen to shut her up. Your only hope is to use your pen on that person before they realize that you've jumped and tell.

Stealthily you move up the path. Two silhouettes greet you as you get close. To your surprise it is Holden, or actually your mystery competitor in Holden's skin, and he hasn't done anything except clamp his hand over Suzy's mouth. As you watch her struggle, you notice he's got a white cloth pressed to her mouth and nose. Slowly, her struggles cease.

There's little you can do now. Well, you could use the pen on the guy in the suit, but that wouldn't be productive and could make matters worse. Instead you decide to make a radical move. As they say in training, if all the planning and technology become no use, do something so stupid and obvious that it will seem to blend in. So that's what you do.

"Whoa oh whoa oh whoa! Party! Party! Party! Hale to the bride and groom. Everyone celebrate nude."

You run past a shocked Holden and unconscious Suzy then through the bushes into the reception. You continue screaming manically as you weave through the dancers and the standing guests. With it now being dark and the lights limited plus the pulsating music, Kurt's skin you're wearing is not recognizable but you do draw several men to yell, "Right on." "Go for it." "Let's go for it!" as you exit down another path out of sight.

"Security. Security. We have a streaker headed towards Lover's Maze." you hear squawking out of several walkie-talkies. "Make that multiple streakers," comes a few seconds later. Obviously, some of the more inebriated must have shucked their clothes and followed you, just as you hoped.

Quickly you circle and see a pile of clothes along the edge of the bushes and one person hanging back laughing. A little stealth again and the fact that everyone is looking the other way where you and the others disappeared allows you the opportunity that you've been waiting for. You point the pen and shoot the person behind everyone then dash across, scoop up the new body suit and their clothes, then disappear down a path away from the commotion.

As you're running, you pull on the suit without missing a step and barely slowing down. It's a talent that got you special recognition during training and a free night of R&R with the suit of your choice. It didn't actually work out as well as you'd hoped, but the skill now proves itself useful as you reappear in less than a minute with no one the wiser.

Standing in the shadows at the edge of the reception area, you consider your options. The diversion has sent security scattering making it easy for you to get away. The guy you've bagged is just an old friend of Alexandra's who she hadn't seen in years, high school actually. He probably got the invitation along with everyone in her high school who got spammed by Alexandra's parents hoping for the most gifts. He thought it would be fun to get a free meal and party with the rich and famous, something he never was able to do then, or now, being of a much lower class. Too bad because he seems to be a nice guy and even had a crush on Alexandra back then. He's not a loser, just a shy geeky type who plays video games and writes fantasy adventure stories in his spare time. His job is much less exciting but pays quite well.

Alexandra is hopelessly staggering around as if she's still dancing to a very different drummer. You remember how Carma set her up with the drugs and booze, so she's probably completely out of it. However, nobody seems to notice, or care, except one. Carma is watching her closely slowly sipping some fruity-looking drink. Holden has just come back from dealing with Suzy and is purposely walking towards Carma. He probably now knows of Carma's plan, so maybe he thinks she was involved with Suzy. Hopefully, Suzy hasn't become collateral damage.

The situation seems so open up for you now. You can easily just walk by Alexandra and swipe the Bloom with your talented fingers. She would never feel it disappear. Although you could be seen by anyone and most likely Carma who's eyes hover like a vulture. Instead you can just walk by and whisper that there's a surprise for her down one of the paths linking it to Holden or her dad, or remind her of high school and ask for a dance taking her away while nobody pays attention. She'd do just about anything from a suggestion at this point. Off down a path, she'd trip and lose the Bloom. It would be a while as she wanders around before anyone notices it's gone and start a search. You'd be long gone with mission accomplished.

However, you're still concerned about the others trying for it as well as the private security guards loitering around conspicuously still wearing sunglasses. Perhaps they're really night vision glasses. You'd like to uncover all those undercover, but that might mean playing musical skins with everyone still here since this test continues to unravel twisting every which way. Although, it might be good intelligence that the organization could use especially if you could get that green pen.

Straightening your suit, you take a deep breath and ask yourself whether you need extra points out of this test, or should you just finish your mission to grab the Scarlet Bloom at the reception and head back?
11221221121212212122212111121112.title: Take on your hunters

112212211212122121222121111211121.content:
The Bloom is your goal, but the green pen...that would be something special, and really prove your worth. You know your decision before you even have pause to think about it.

The pen is, at the moment, with Holden. So you know he's one of the opposition, too. There's a couple of other suspects for the other members of his gang. The security guards are one, each with earphones in that could have concealed their protection against the strange 'fairy dance' you witnessed earlier. Ophelia Vincent is another hot candidate: one of the bridesmaids, she seemed particularly annoyed, rather than confused, when Alexandra stopped dancing. It was a strange reaction. You guess it was 'Rodney' - now 'Holden' that switched out the music, so there's no lead there. And then there's Travis, Maya's fiance. He was wearing some kind of ear buds during the dance, you think. Could he be another possibility? That might mean returning to Maya's lovely form.

"That was pretty wild, wasn't it?" A voice, strong and feminine, greets you. You turn and smile. She's an older woman, maybe in her mid-40s, with a powerful, striking face - the kind you expect to see in a boardroom. Her black hair is flecked with silver, and her bright red lipstick contrasts against the golden jewelry around her neck.

"Excuse me?" You say.

"The streakers. Thank goodness we packed the kids off to the entertainment in another tent, or to bed, to let the adults get on with the serious business. By which I mean drinking." She smiles, and raises a glass to you. "Clarissa Van Lewen. And you are?"

"Rich. Rich Breadworth. Old friend of Alexandra's."

"Oh? So the Vincents still have some old friends? There I was thinking we were the only ones."

You laugh, and so does she, a laugh that rings hollow, echoing with money. "So, are you enjoying this little get-together?"

"Definitely," you say, leaning over to a buffet table and helping yourself to one of the small finger foods. Some kind of seafood; it slips and slithers down your throat. "It's great to see Alex so happy, you know?"

"Of course," Clarissa's smile widens. "Although," she says, tracing a finger along your shirt, "it's not just for her, this wedding. Everyone is entitled to a good time. Some enjoy streaking...I... prefer to lose my clothes somewhere a little more... intimate."

You blush; it's Rich's reaction, but yours too. You're pretty sure you're being hit on. You look down at the wedding ring on her finger.

"Uh, aren't you..."

"Married? Spare me. Do you know what my husband has done today? Kept himself busy and out of the way. Constantly on the phone, making plans, talking to that gastly manager... Rod something? He even had headphones in during the reception. Headphones, I ask you. Probably listening to some sports game. Not exactly what you call attentive, is it? But you, Rich.. you, I am sure, would be very attentive. Very attentive indeed..."

She leans forward, whispering in your ear. "We can slip away, you know. You and I. You'd like that, wouldn't you... Rich?"

You think it through. Out of the corner of your eye, 'Holden' is distracted with Carma. You still have time to snag the Bloom, and you're certain that you could slip into another face at the wedding and get closer to some of your suspects;it should be easy enough to rebuff Clarissa. But Mr Van Lewen, whoever he is, sounds like one of your rivals in disguise, too. It would explain why he's been so neglectful with his wife. And you know that 'Holden' won't be making a move until the bridal suite. Perhaps you could head off with Clarissa, back to the hotel. There, you could either switch with her and grab Mr Van Lewen, or find someone Holden and ambush him as he returns to the hotel.
112212211212122121222121111211121.title: An Unexpected Proposition

choices: You passioantely kiss her using your best technique.
Grab the Bloom and her pen and run.
1122122112121221212221211112111212.content:
With all the craziness going on, you actually consider the offer. From the guy's memories, he's never done an older woman. In fact, it scares him due to his own inexperience.

"Really, I'm flattered that you'd consider me, bu ..."

"Then what are we waiting for." She loops her arm in yours and drags you toward a path through the bushes.

"Ah, um, won't they miss you?" you try to stop being kidnapped (that's a pun)

"Oh, don't be silly. It's not like I'm kryptonite and you're superman, although maybe I can help there."

Holy crap. This woman is not going to take a no. Maybe if I use the pen and ... Wait! That's the safety code phrase: kryptonite and superman.

Immediately your mind pulls up the proper rely. "Peter Parker wasn't afraid of spiders."

"Wonder Woman has a golden lariat."

"Supercar was a marionette show."

"Do you have any idea what's going on here?"

"The Purple Pimpernel was a sissy."

"Right. Look lad, there's five students taking the same test and one Type A trying to sabotage everything. None of them know about any of the others."

"Why are you telling me this?"

"I'm really horny, and you need experience," she purrs licking her lips.

"But what about the Bloom?"

"You mean this?" She holds up the necklace causing it to glow in the moonlight. You turn to look back, but you've rounded the hedge and can't see Alexandra any more to know if this is real or not.

The stone is fake.

It's why you couldn't help but giggle. The whole plot from the Organization, and the whole set-up of Carma's, it's all absolutely pointless. The Vincent family is struggling financially. They think the Parrys are their way to a fortune, just as Holden believes Alexandra will bring him untold riches. Carma is planning to scheme, steal and murder for a fake stone. The real one is sat in a bank vault a little more than five miles away: the Van Lewens bought the real gem, and are holding it for the Vincents until they can regain their fortune from the Parrys... you laugh again.

The Van Lewens have the Bloom. The Vincents are scheming to regain it after a financial injection from the Parrys. The Parrys, meanwhile, are trying to get rich from the Vincents. And while Alexandra Vincent has the fake Bloom around her neck, her best friend Carma and her future husband, both secret lovers, are plotting to steal the necklace and install Carma as the wealthy bride.

A nest of vipers. A soap opera dilemma. It's all become so clear. This is the test the Organization set. The whole point of today isn't the Bloom at all. It's to see if you could survive in such a twisting, labyrinthine world where everyone has a scheme. Carma, you realize, was zapped earlier as either a trap, or to prevent you from gaining her knowledge. That way you'd have been surprised by the plot and would have to respond.

There's no point in continuing the wedding. The whole mission is just a setup. You might as well slip away and abort... or slip away and get into that bank vault. That would be easier said than done, of course. The only people with access are the Van Lewens - of course, they're at the wedding, but they're not going to be able to quietly slip away. Or you'll have to find a way into the vault through one of the employees; maybe even one of the guards in their sharp suits. And that's assuming you can even get out of the hotel.

You return to what you were taught in your training. The actions you take don't necessarily have to be in character. They just have to be rationalized and explained by your disguise. The worst thing that can happen to you is exposure. And if you need the leverage, you can twist a situation to your advantage if you must. And, while it wouldn't be stolen at the reception, there's a way you could take the Bloom, too.

You smile, and turn to Carma, Alexandra's look of barely-restrained adoration in your eyes. You give her palm a squeeze, and think back to the moment Alexandra had burst into her room earlier. She was going to tell Carma how she felt then, too. You turn and, leaning up to her despite your heels, push your perfect lips against hers. Carma's eyes widen, and for once she looks uncertain. The evil bitch doesn't know how to react.

"Alexan..."

"Hush," you say, putting Alexandra on the offensive as you bat your eyelids. "Carm, I have to tell you this. Before it's too late, I have to tell you." Tears are already beginning to well up in your eyes as you let Alexandra's emotions take over. Her breath judders out. "You remember the night, don't you? The night we got a little tipsy, and entwined ourselves? It was so perfect, Carm. It was what I've dreamed about since then. I don't want to marry Holden. I don't care about the Parrys - that's my family. I want you. I always have. Please, Carm... please say yes."

Carma's unable to keep up her pretense. She just looks staggered by the revelation. This, you know, is your chance. You provide Alexandra's face with a look of utter horror.

"You don't... do you? You don't think of me that way? You don't feel it too? No... no, you don't, do you? You don't want me!" Alexandra's tears begin to run. Carma still stands there, trying to compose herself, only looking shocked, stunned and unsure. You grip the Bloom in one hand, grasping the clasp in the other, dramatically bringing it off and shaking it at the stunned maid of honor. "All this! All this is meaningless, Carma! There's only me and you! I can't go through with this! I just can't!"

You run out of the private room, a hysterical bride, fleeing her own wedding. Nobody will question if you've "dropped" the Bloom in your mad flight. And the whole hotel will be abuzz with news of what happened. All focus will be on Alexandra.

When you find a new skin to hide in, or even slip back to Kurt's, everyone's attention will be on the wedding, and not on you slipping away. You've explained everything that has happened, too: nobody will think something even stranger has taken place. Perhaps even more importantly, you'll have saved Alexandra's life. Her family may face ruin, and it's likely her love for Carma will go painfully unrequited, but she'll be alive. And nobody's going to question a hysterical bride fainting before she walked up the aisle.

You dash out of the room, and face a three-way corridor ahead of you. Left is out: that leads to the wedding, and while you could cause surprise as the bride bursting out into the garden, you'd be unlikely to have an opportunity to escape. Forward leads back to the spa from earlier: you could definitely find a place to swap there, perhaps into that beautician who was working in a side room. And then there's right, back into the hotel proper. You're pleased you took the time to scout out the location. There's plenty of options to find a hotel guest, or work your way into the gardens, perhaps to swap to one of the Van Lewens.

You make your choice and, struggling in your heels and wedding gown, flee, Bloom in hand.
11221221121212212122212111221.title: Runaway Bride

choices: Trade Bob for the Bloom's current owner.
112212211212122121222121112211.content:
Your epiphany has freed you of all worry and stress. The carefree child in you skips happily down the hall towards the spa where there are more rooms to hide and switch, though fewer people. It is an exhilarating feeling even as Alexandra's neurotic memories fill you with a sense of doom, ... no death, or really suicide. She has contemplated this many times before; yet with the help of drugs and therapy, she has lingered in a fantasy and avoided taking the final step out of this world. You hope that continues after you abandon her.

This thing is so fucked up, you think. So fucked up even that you're tempted to get back to the wedding and zap as many as possible to get a complete inventory of this craziness, but you don't.

The first door is an exit stairway from the floors above. Coming up is the entrance to the spa. There's a reception area inside that is sure to be staffed, and you aren't currently inconspicuous enough to just slip in. However, there's at most one person that a lucky shot could skin before they realized you were there. Emphasis is on lucky. Maybe you should take the stairs even in the bulky gown. Hopefully, there's a room or someone you can find up there before someone else finds you.

Just as you are about to eenie-meenie-minie-moe, the stairwell door opens and someone steps out in front of you not looking back. Before you think, you pen the person, and they shrivel to the floor. Must be your training as you grab the skin and clothes and are in the stairwell a second after you realize it.

No time to even see who your new costume is, only to check the opening (you're not going to be caught again) - it's clean, so you just pop out the back of Alexandra and climb in to your new disguise. There's probably just a minute before someone comes down the hall so you get dressed and flee back upstairs once Alexandra is sealed back and starts to inflate.

As the memories flood in, they lead you onto the third floor with fake Bloom in your pocket. Your room is 302, but it won't take long before the resort is on lockdown. No time to go in your room since escape will be tricky if not impossible if you're not gone in the next five minutes. Fortunately, your new person has a car in the lot. All you have to do is get there. Elevator too slow. Can't go back down these stairs. Out the window looks like the best choice.

Robert Foxworth, retired salesman invited to speak at the annual Casket Hardware conference that starts tomorrow morning. He was just taking a stroll around the resort and wanted to check out the facilities, not that he would use them although he really needs to. He's sixty years old, pudgy, balding with a scattering of white hairs and a beard that make him look more intelligent than he is. Not athletic, but hopefully that won't be necessary. You just need to get to the bank and find a way to switch this fake for the real Scarlet Bloom.

Quickly scanning through the window at the end of the hall as you raise it, you see the roof of the second floor meeting rooms and an access door at the far end. The wedding is taking place at the other end of the resort, but this is where the reception will be held. The drop is just a few feet and about fifty meters to the door. Piece of cake, except when you reach the door. It's locked. Nothing in his pockets except a bit of change from the soda machine and handkerchief. Then his memories remind you to check his wallet where he keeps his bank cards and an old paper clip. You eyes pop happily remembering the lock-pick class. A minute later you're down the stairs and out the side door at the edge of the parking lot.

The logical thing is to head straight to the bank where the Bloom is - and "Bob" happens to have an account - and get into the safety deposit box room and retrieve the Bloom. Of course, you don't know what box it's in, but nabbing a bank employee should allow you access to records to find out. Then again, everything that has seemed logical so far has been a complete contradiction. Perhaps going back and grabbing one of the Van Lewens might be in order. It's a bit trickier especially having the fake Bloom, but the wedding disruption should allow you an excuse to duck out to the bank. Maybe stash the trinket in Bob's car. You only wonder what bizarre trait one of them will have. Bob seems quite normal, at least so far. You can't believe that the Organization setup everyone, but then again ...?
112212211212122121222121112211.title: Another switch and run

choices: Stick with Bob, get into the vault
1122122112121221212221211122111.content:
Bob is quite normal, you muse, scratching at his beard. Overweight, ageing, with high cholesterol and diabetes, but there's nothing weird about him. That comes as a relief. All you want to do is escape a wedding falling into chaos, where everyone seems to have a dirty secret or insane intention.

The problem is the bank itself. As Bob, you could get into the vault - perhaps. But banks have cameras. If you try and swap with any employee, you're going to be caught on footage. There's a lot of risk involved. You'd have to somehow convince an employee to step away from the cameras. It might be possible in the safety deposit room, but then you'd have to return to the computer to find out which number is owned by the Van Lewens. The only person that would know that information immediately would be the manager, and, as it's a weekend, you can't imagine they'd be at work.

You walk up to Bob's car, and pull out his credit card. It's an old model, and while 'he' has left his car keys in this room, your lock-picking skills again make themselves useful. You slide into the driver's seat, grunting from Bob's weight, and look at yourself in the rear view mirror. Beads of sweat have formed on your balding scalp.

"You're getting slow, old man," you remark to your own reflection, before pulling open the compartment under the wheel. In a moment you've hotwired the car, and are fleeing the chaos behind you.

*****


"Yes sir, can I help you?" The bank's greeter, a smartly dressed young man, looks at you expectantly. You smile, and let your distinguished voice set his mind at ease.

"Not today, thank you. I'm just weighing up a financial transaction."

"Well, if I can be of any assistance, let me know." The young man walks away. The bank is cool, calm and virtually empty. A couple of tellers are helping customers: a businessman is talking finance, an expectant mother is patiently counting out receipts, an Asian man approaching middle age is arguing about a cheque that seems to have bounced. In the corner, the customer assistant for the vault is sat at the desk, waiting to see if anyone requires service. The bank's cameras record all, and security guards are posted throughout.

You walk over to a stack of leaflets, picking one up along with an impossibly small pen, and take a seat, pretending to fill it out. You look around while you do so, assessing your options.

The direct route is to access Bob's account at the bank, and request a safety deposit box. That would get you into the right room, and then you'd have to see if you could swap into an employee without raising suspicion. Bank security is tight, though, and there might be a better alternative.

On the wall opposite your seat is a picture of a smiling, well-turned out woman, probably in her late 30s or early 40s. She's wearing heavy makeup, deliberately designed to give her a professional, confident look. She's in a sharp suit, with black hair cut into a voluminous long bob. The plaque underneath reads: K. Wendel, manager.

This brings a thought to your mind. The moment Alexandra recovers, the wedding is going to be plunged into chaos. The first thing people are going to try and do is locate the Scarlet Bloom. It's a fake, but that doesn't seem to be common knowledge - Alexandra hadn't even told Carma - and there were security guards looking after it. The security company is going to inform the bank, who will be forced to check on the real Bloom. That means an emergency procedure is going to begin, and the manager, wherever she is, is going to be called in, along with the local sheriff, to check the Bloom is safe.

That could be far simpler, you decide. You walk over to the young greeter, and politely ask to borrow a phone directory. He looks at you for a moment, but then complies: Robert Foxworth is too old for the internet, and something as old school as a phone directory is exactly the kind of thing he might ask for. A few moments of flicking through, and you find what you're looking for. There's only one 'Wendel' listed in the directory, and the address is provided.

You'll have to move quickly: you're only a couple of minutes from the Bloom being reported stolen, the security guards determining its missing, and the emergency protocol springing in to action. Either you can go ahead with your original plan to use Robert to get into the vault, or you can take the slightly longer, but possibly safer, route: either head to the police station and replace the local sheriff, or head to the manager's house and try your luck there.
1122122112121221212221211122111.title: Bank On It

choices: The first box comes easy and reveals the Scarlet Bloom
No Bloom in the first box
11221221121212212122212111221111.content:
Being Bob is just so comfortable. His whole body is so relaxed even if out of shape. He really doesn't have a care. Talking at the conference is something he's done his whole career. In fact, that's the best thing going for using him - he can easily talk to anyone with great ability of persuasion. Just what you need to get info and find the box with the Scarlet Bloom.

The probability of swapping with the bank manager or the Sheriff is rather low considering what you'd have to do. Assuming Ms. Wendel is even at home, getting her alone to zap might be difficult. You might even have to expose Bob which would be a downgrade on your test having anyone you assumed be recognized. And what of the Sheriff? Is he out roaming in his cruiser or sitting behind his desk with other officers around. He could be out fishing in a number of secluded spots or watching a ball game with a bunch of other beer-belly ex-high school jock has-beens.

Lastly, there's no guarantee that the security company will know to check the bank. The Van Lewens may not want to alert the authorities and have it widely known that they didn't trust the Vincents and their daughter to let her wear the real Scarlet Bloom and provided a fake. More than likely, they would just quietly check the safe deposit box not involving either the manager or Sheriff. Then you would totally have blown it and get a failing grade, possibly busted down to a Type 3 which would be worse then stuck in a green-slime suit and lose your personal identity forever.

Yep. Staying Bob is really the best chance at success; and if you play it right, you might not even have to switch to make the switch. The last thing you want is to step into another of the organization's screwy setups that would continue or start a new soap opera of personalities.

"Young man," you again address the greeter. "I will be in need of setting up a safety deposit box. Could you direct me on what I need to do?"

"Certainly, sir," he replies with a smile and standing. "Please follow me. The person who handles this is Miss Charlotte. She will help you with the forms and walk you through opening the box and how the keys work."

You approach a desk just outside the vault area where sits a young woman, twenty-five at most, who is immaculately attired in a blue blazer over a white blouse that is stretched to its maximum across her chest, You would think if she breathed that the button would snap. She has a mousy face accented with a button nose supporting large round glasses that magnify her hazel eyes which are expertly lined and shadowed. Her auburn hair is pulled to the back in a barrette rather than a pony tail so it hangs evenly spread across her neck reaching just inches below he shoulders. Bangs come down in front exposing just a half inch of forehead above her neatly plucked eyebrows.

"Miss Charlotte, this is Mr. ... I'm sorry. I didn't ask your name."

"Foxworth. Bob Foxworth. Well, really Robert but everyone calls me Bob, so please do, and ..." Noticing her name tag on the blazer, Abigail B. Charlotte, you add, "May I call you Abby?"

She slightly blushes and smiles demurely as Bob's charm starts to work. "You can, but everyone calls be Abs," she offers standing to shake your hand. As you do, a quick glance reveals that she definitely has trim abs when her blouse billows open at her waist.

You thank the young man before sitting and then repeat your request to Abs. It's only about five minutes of paperwork and your flattering repartee before she has you wait while she enters it all in a computer. You banter about the double work of it since you could have entered the info directly. She agrees but states the bank likes to use their old process. She reads the paper form moving her glasses back and forth like a telescope as she types things in, stopping several times asking you for clarification. When she turns the screen for you to confirm, there's a couple errors you point out making her blush again. The color in her face makes her quite attractive.

Once done, she spins the monitor for you to confirm and pushes over the keyboard for you to type in your passcode and check the acceptance boxes of the long description of terms.

"May take me a bit to read this. Hope you don't mind. Just an old habit."

"Of course, Mr. Fox ..."

"Please, Bob," you correct with your best sales smile.

"Of course, Bob. While you do that, let me get the keys."

You stand as she does being very old-school polite, and she blushes again. You can tell you've made a solid contact and should be able to sell her on helping you when needed.

When you sit, you notice that there is another tab open behind the Terms of Agreement which just happens to be a list of deposit boxes showing which are available. Obviously, she checked that to know what one she could get for you. Little did she realize that it also shows the Van Lewens boxes. They have two, unfortunately, both of the right size to hold the Bloom. Your name is on the next sequential box to theirs that is listed as just having gotten in the past two months. The other is years old. Hopefully, that means it was recently acquired just for the Scarlet Bloom

Your training allowed you to flick the screen quick enough that no one could tell. You were also fortunate, that cameras were not focused on your back and could not see the screen, probably for customer privacy when entering their bank passcode. Bob seemed to be good luck, and you were now fully committed to staying with him as long as possible.

The only thing now would be how to cover your opening of the the Van Lewens box. You know it takes two keys to release it - yours and the bank's that Abs carries that works in all the boxes. Each customer's key is unique. Of course, your lock picking is unlikely to require either.

As she leads you in, you're the only two in the vault having passed through the big gate using Abs and the vault guard's electronic security cards. As you go in, you chat to Abs about why the boxes don't use cards in this technology age. Again a blush and roll of her eyes as she explains the old mentality of the bank's management. "So old and cheap," she whispers in confidence, "that they don't even have camera's in the vault, only coming and going."

Bob's sales pitch is working well on your behalf as she continues to divulge information. Now all you need to do is get the Van Lewens box and switch the fake Bloom in your pocket with the real one and leave that in Bob's new box.
11221221121212212122212111221111.title: Bob heads into the vault

choices: Your first mission as a Type 1
112212211212122121222121112211111.content:
The rest is easy. It doesn't take much to persuade Abs to give you some time alone, after having removed your deposit box from the wall with your keys: a quick request and she's out the door, pointing to a buzzer to contact her when you're ready to leave. The second she's walked out the door you cross the room, pull out Bob's cards, and get to work on the next box over. It takes a little work, but you manage to pick the locks and open the box. And there, gleaming in the hard metal, is your prize.

The Scarlet Bloom. The real, genuine gem. It sparkles even more than its fake versions, the deep red tint inside catching the vault's harsh lighting perfectly. quickly, you take the fake Bloom and slip it inside. Then all you need to do is gather up the Bloom, place it in your pocket, and close up Bob's box. A quick buzz later and Abs is ready to lead you out of the vault again.

You can't help but grin wildly as Robert Foxworth walks out of the bank, or when you hit the rendezvous and leave him in the safety of his own car, your handler providing you with a new set of clothes.

*****


"So," you can't help but ask, "How did I do?"

"This was a test," your handler reports back. "So we through you a curveball. In fact, we through you a lot of curveballs. The test wasn't so much about this trinket" - the Bloom is held out on its chain - " as whether you could navigate a particularly difficult social situation. The Vincent-Parry wedding was always going to be full of strong, deeply unpleasant characters. And yet you managed to get through it without being noticed."

"The wedding was called off, though," you say.

"Yes, but that doesn't matter. Alexandra Vincent did that; after she came to, she continued to try and run, hysterically calling for Carma Hamilton. Who, as you failed to note, was a little trap we set. Carma was caught by a pen yesterday, and we deliberately set her up as a potential greener." This seems to be slang for a trap suit. "You didn't see that. But, when her thoughts started to come through, you didn't panic. You stayed calm and dealt with the situation."

"So I didn't fail?"

"Let me finish. You realized the Bloom wasn't being kept at the wedding, so you went to get it. That showed initiative. And your decisions to switch made it very hard for us to track you - and near-impossible for anyone else. It left a spate of 'fainting' attacks in the hotel. You could have used the white pen function to explain their missing 10 minutes: it would have been neater. However, the hotel is now testing its rooms for carbon monoxide, and it hasn't raised an eyebrow. So it's hard to fault you on that."

"Go on?"

"Your switches were in character and trying to lead you to a goal. You switched far more than most agents would even attempt: six different skins. And you pulled it off. Nobody is questioning what happened at the hotel. In short, we're very impressed. Very impressed."

"So I passed?"

"You did. The only thing damaging your grade is that you didn't spot Carma Hamilton was a greener. But, when you realized the situation you were in, you adjusted beautifully. Taking the bride was a good touch."

"She was the only option available," you report.

"Regardless. It gave you the information you needed. Which is why we're offering you a choice. You can continue as a Type 2. Get some rest and relaxation, but we've got a range of field missions that require someone with your abilities. A little corporate espionage at a high-tech lab, framing a playboy in Las Vegas, manipulating an entire small town council to grant land rights to a particular company. But we're also going to offer you a bigger role. If you are interested, you will be upgraded to a Type 1. You'd still be required to keep your identity fluid, as you would a Type 2. But the missions will be more final: assassinate a corrupt businessman disguised as a particular person, or making it appear an accident; clean up someone else's mess by erasing evidence of the Organization. Arrange a bank account to siphon us money to us from inside a multinational. Alter the path of a satellite from a military base. It won't be a quick mission, either. You might have to stay in situ for a week, impersonating someone or switching identities as required, constantly studying a developing situation. Or you might have less than an hour to solve a problem.

"The choice is yours."
112212211212122121222121112211111.title: A Study in Scarlet

choices: Find a new face on main street
Head to the cinema or tavern
1122122112121221212221211122111112.content:
You get out of the car and stretch your muscles. You're in small town America, up in the remote wilds. This is Cameron's Peak, named after the local mountain. There's a chill wind in the air, and just getting out into the air sends a chill up your spine. Your first mission is going to require a lot of swapping. Which is just how you like it.

The brief is simple. Three days ago the town was taken over, though they'd never realize it. Through another agent's incompetence, a black and brown pen fell into the hands of a gang of criminals called the Coburn Gang: Trent and Josh Coburn, and their accomplice Irene Copper. They've since used the pens for a spree of bank robberies, and the trail leads directly to Cameron's Peak, where it stops. The Organization suspects they're lying low, enjoying their money in borrowed bodies for the time being, waiting for the Organization's chase to peter out.

It's not going to. They don't realize it, but they've painted themselves into a corner. Organization agents are currently acting as the local highway patrol, stopping anyone coming in and out of the town for a quick test with the white pen to make sure they are who they claim to be. They've got to be in the town, somewhere. Probably in someone with power - the mayor, or local sheriff, or one of the wealthy families that have holiday homes here.

It's your job to track them down and catch them, all without raising suspicion or attracting their attention. The Organization suspects they've probably split up, taking different lives, each unaware who the other actually is. You're also on strict instructions not to just shoot everyone and see what turns up. You're to investigate their possible lives by getting close to them, observing them and identifying them. They don't have any of their host's memories, so it should be fairly straightforward to spot people acting out of character. Once you spot one, you're to get them out of the skin with the white pen, zap them and contain them.

Your intel is sketchy, but there are a few key members of town whose identity they could have adopted. The only question is where to start. It's a Saturday, so the Mayor will be at home with his family - if he's really the mayor. The Sheriff is likely to be on duty at the station, although the only cop you can see is a deputy, a black woman with hair beaded and tied up in a knot behind her head, snoozing in her cruiser on the main road. As for the richer families, you'll have to find a way into their mansion. Maybe someone is down in the main town, looking for entertainment or having gone shopping? There's a local cinema, tavern, pizzeria and a small arcade of shops. You're sure there's someone there you can become.

You frown at the task ahead. It's going to be tough, but the first step is to find someone close to one of the possible candidates.
1122122112121221212221211122111112.title: Manhunt

112212211212122121222121112211112.content:
The rest is easy. It doesn't take much to persuade Abs to give you some time alone, after having removed your deposit box from the wall with your keys: a quick request and she's out the door, pointing to a buzzer to contact her when you're ready to leave. The second she's walked out the door you cross the room, pull out Bob's cards, and get to work on the next box over. It takes a little work, but you manage to pick the locks and open the box.

There's nothing there. Just an empty box, devoid of any contents. The bare metal stares back at you.

"It's not in the other one, either." Ab's voice resounds behind you. You never heard her enter the vault again. You spin around in surprise, reaching for your pen.

"Don''t," she says, leveling her own pen at you. "You'll never make it before I zap you."

You let a look of puzzlement cross Bob's face. "What do you..."

Abs shakes her head. "Drop the act. You're a trainee, same as me. You've been tasked to get the Bloom. You worked out it wasn't at the wedding at all, so headed straight here. Only problem is, it's not here either."

Your mind races, but suddenly everything is starting to make more sense. The whole crazy wedding has been ludicrous, a delirious whirlwind of insanity. It's a giant set-up. The soap opera lives of the Holdens and Parrys and Hamiltons are real enough, but it's been a playground - a proving ground - for trainees. Whoever passes the test gets to stay. You wonder how many other trainees...

"There's at least four of us," Abs continues. "I made two of them. Didn't make you, I think; not until you came here and started breaking in to the vault. I caught you taking a look at the computer. This pretty face is perfect for setting people off guard. The mousy glasses, the barrette? She was too inconspicuous to pass up. I just waited to see who'd come for the Bloom. She has no idea it's already gone... which is hardly surprising. She has no idea what's kept in the boxes."

"So who knows?" You ask, crossing Bob's arms. There are no cameras in the vault, so you might as well listen up.

"Wendel, the bank manager. She's home with the family right now; why work weekends when you have staff? The security detachment, perhaps. And of course Clarissa Van Lewen, who visited the vault with Ms Wendel late last night. My guess is that one of them was our handler, who decided to take the real Bloom and plant it at the wedding."

"Wait," you sigh. "The Bloom is back at the hotel? I just left there."

"It might be. Can't be sure. The Van Lewen estate is another possibility. Or Wendel might have had it relocated to another branch. Ugh... Abigail's here's memories tell me she's a total bitch, and was chewing her out about security down here. Of course, it's Wendel's fault there's no cameras, but Abs is too timid to fight back. Anyway, I've been waiting until Abigail's break so I can sneak off to the diner, swap skins and head back."

"Back to that mad house?" You refer, of course, to the wedding. "I don't know if the wedding is even going ahead. The bride did some pretty strange things."

"Even better," Miss Abigail Charlotte grins. "Nothing duller than a wedding reception. If the wedding is called off, people will be scattered around the hotel. Security will be tight, but everyone's still going to make a grab for the Bloom."

"But which? If there's four of us, there's at least five fakes, plus the real gem."

"There's nothing in our orders that said we can't work together. We could partner up. If we grab three stones each - from the others and from Alexandra - they'd have to pass us both. The others don't know they've been made, yet. Abigail's break is up in five minutes. You and I could grab a couple and head back to the hotel. Unless you prefer to work alone? Oh, don't worry, I'm not going to zap you here. Two people into a vault, one out? Questions would be asked, even if it would be easy to cover up."

You nod, slowly, as you consider your options.
112212211212122121222121112211112.title: Empty Handed

1122122112121221212221211122111121.content:
"All right," you say, nodding. You're not sure if this offer is genuine, and you don't really care. Right now, it's your best move. And ultimately there's nothing to say you have to keep your end of the bargain: you could always use 'her' to do the dirty work.

"In that case, we need to get out of here." Miss Charlotte is seems open about the predicament you're in. It's not possible to zap someone in the vault - it would rouse suspicions. "But first things first, we need to make sure the 'Bloom' is here."

"Well, I don't have a copy of it," you say.

"I do," Miss Charlotte says. "Upstairs though, come on."

You both step into the lift, riding it up back to the bank floor. From the clean, sterile serenity of the vault, the sunlight and sound feel almost jarringly loud. You scratch Bob's beard, following the prim, smart walk of the apparently young bank clerk, trying to remember she's really one of your rivals. It's hard under such a smart uniform. She turns from her desk, side-stepping into a private office.

"This way, sir," she says, a businesslike smile. You nod and step in, acting the customer all the way, your finger resting on your own pen. If she makes one wrong move...

She doesn't. She steps to the desk and opens a drawer, revealing the light pink, glistening gemstone replica to your eyes.

"OK," Miss Charlotte says. "The next step is to... shit."

You look up, shifting Bob's frame to glance in the direction she's pointing. For the briefest of moments your heart freezes, then pounds with unrelenting force: you just fell for the oldest trick in the book, the 'look that-a-way'. But the strange sensation of the zap doesn't come. Instead, you see exactly why she's pointing.

Walking through the main lobby, dressed in a smart cream blouse and grey business suit, is the woman from the photo earlier: the bank manager. Here to check the Bloom, as per the arrangements with the security guards. All hell must be breaking loose back at Cedar Pines.

"She's going to see it's missing. There's no way I can sleight it into the vault without..."

"You don't need to," you correct hastily, pulling the draw strings and turning the small office blinds to conceal your presence. "Just be Abigail Charlotte, and get her in here."

Your waifish, young partner smiles, a vicious gleam shining beneath her glasses. "Good idea."

Moments later, and the surprised woman steps into the office, accompanied by her young employee who seals the door behind her. There's a look of confusion, before the manager's skin collapses to the floor, her suit and blouse crumpling beneath it. Your cohort leans forward, the buttons in front of her chest still straining, and passes the skin over. You appraise it, gathering up the large, black strands of hair that make up the bob. You begin to get out of your current disguise, and...

"Are you going to leave?"

"What?"

"I'm not going to reveal who I really am. You know the rules."

Miss Charlotte grins. "All right, sir," she acknowledges. "I'll be at my desk. Come grab me when you're done."

*****


Ten minutes later, having explained to a customer that he'd collapsed in the manager's office, both Katherine Wendel - 40, married with kids - and her assistant Abigail Charlotte are on the road, Kathy's neatly manicured nails at the wheel of her car. You shift, exploring your new form. For an older woman, Kathy's body is attractive: the heavy makeup on her face works, and there's something incredible about the volume of black locks that bounce playfully on your neck. You look out of her eyes, checking the mirror and the town that's slowly disappearing behind you. Kathy's thoughts are about pot roast that she's preparing tonight. Your thoughts are the Bloom. You've already lied through your teeth, telling the worried owner the Bloom - the real one - is safe and secure in the vault. The truth, however, is far different.

You've got a mission, now. You and Abs are going to track down your opponents and steal their fakes. Then you're going to steal the real gem, where ever it may be. The wedding might be in chaos, but that doesn't change the rules of the game.

You turn the car into the Cedar Pines resort, adjusting Kathy's hair and flicking it out of her collar, smoothing the ruffles of her suit. She dressed in a hurry when the alert came in, and she's a woman fastidious about her appearance.

"So what's the plan?" Abs asks, beside you. "We take them one at a time?"

"We identify them first," you say, Kathy's voice - a trickling Mid West drawl that seems to elongate every thought - sounding out into the car. "They might not be holding the same identity as before. We're effectively starting again."

"Not entirely," Abs says. "We know they'll want to stick around. So we have a shorter list of suspects."

"True enough," you admit. "The question is whether this is the right form to narrow that list down. Kathy Wendel isn't known to them, and nor is Abigail Charlotte. We look like bank personnel; they might try and slip into our appearance in the hope of learning something."

"That could be useful, if we have each other's backs."

"Or dangerous. I could always park around near the spa. There's bound to be someone we could intercept, what with the convention that's happening. We could shed these skins, leave them in a guest's room, and explore the hotel. Either we could grab a staff member and go solo, or we could try and find a couple and impersonate them. Nobody's going to suspect that, are they?"

Abs nods. "I don't mind either way," she decides. "It's your call."

1122122112121221212221211122112.content:
Going straight to the bank is your first thought. It's the fastest way to make sure you get the Bloom. The drive isn't far and you have the tools that would allow you to get in, grab it, and get out. But you stop, you need to think about this logically. Some times going with your gut is the way to go. Instinct can be a powerful guiding force and during your training you were told that more experienced operatives are able to intuit what to do, working on the fly and instinctively knowing the best path to take to get something done.

But those are, again, experienced operatives and you are most definitely not an experienced. Hell, this whole thing is basically one long training exercise. A sort of extended final exam or the Organization's version of a Master's thesis. You don't have the experience needed to trust your gut. Doing that got you into the trap that was Carma Hamilton and it's only through stopping and thinking things through that you were able to escape. Of course, your trainers had said, not all agents are able to go by instinct. Just as many take things slower, more measured. Each has their own strengths, their own way of doing things after all.

Whether you'll be able to go with your gut or not, you're certainly not in that position. You're in Bob Foxworth right now and you got there pretty much due to you panicking. It was a desperate gamble.

So why take the risk? The bank will be guarded, there will be cameras. This viper's nest is bad enough. You're still just a kid and you're stressed as is. Better to take a slower approach, something relatively safer. You turn back and re-enter the resort. You'll become one of the Van Lewens. There is still risk in becoming one of them to be sure but it's risks associated with keeping up the identity and making nobody the wiser. So far, however, you've been doing well not arousing suspicion in any of your guises if you do say so yourself so it's a lesser risk and one far less likely to put your back against the wall with no way out like going up to the bank as Bob could.

You take quick note of the information you committed to memory before leaving for the assignment. The Van Lewen are a family long involved in the financial sector, going back to the Gilded Age in the when Ambrose van Lewen founded a financial services company that would eventually go on to become Van Lewen Financial which owns the bank that Bob uses, VL Century; so called because when current Van Lewen patriarch, Marcus van Lewen, founded the bank it was 100 years to the day of Van Lewen Financial's founding.

Marcus van Lewen is a man with a bit of an aged handsomeness of 54. His immediate family members, the ones that are with him right now at the wedding, are his 46-year-old wife Clarissa, 20-year-old son (and heir) Daniel, and 14-year-old daughter Alexis. You will have to become one of those four.

You make your way to their room which your files told you was room 320, on the same floor as Bob's funny enough. It's locked, of course, but thankfully your training means that getting past an electronic lock, the type that a hotel would use, is quite easy. Inside the room you look for a place where you can hide out. There's a closet, open just a crack, and you make your way over to it. You remove the Bob suit tossing the suit and related clothing under the nearest bed before heading in to the closet and waiting.

It's about 15 minutes before you hear voices and the Van Lewens, all four of them, enter the room.

"I told you this was a waste of time, dear." the mature, cultured voice of Clarissa says as they step in. "Honestly the Vincents are in such dire financial straits that they give us their most important possession as collateral. You expected anything less than dysfunction?"

"I expected that, for once, even a family such as the Vincents would be able to show some sense of decorum." Marcus replies with a sigh.

"So what do we do now?" Asks Daniel. "We getting out of here or...?"

"I don't know." Marcus replies, "For the time being your mother and I will go back to the reception area, mingle a bit, try to assess the situation and smooth things over between the Vincents and Parrys. We'll be back in an hour or so."

"Good, gives me time to do a little looking around." Daniel replies in a pleased tone, "There was this really cute waitress down in the restaurant and..."

"Yes, that's very good son, just remember be back here in an hour." Marcus replies.

"What about you, honey?" Clarissa asks her daughter.

You watch Alexis give a bored shrug, "I guess I'll sit around here until you get back."

There's your target. You watch as Marcus and Clarissa leave. Then Daniel. The door closes and it's just you and Alexis alone in the room. You take the pen, making sure you grabbed it out of Bob's pocket before discarding his stuff under the bed, aim and fire. The girl immediately shrivels, deflates, and crumples to the ground. Gotcha!

You emerge from the closet and go over to the now deflated Alexis suit. You pick it up and hesitate for just a moment. So far you've been people around your own age or older. She's still close, just a few years younger. Still for a brief moment you pause but you quickly shake the hesitation and step in. Your legs become slimmer and shorter, but stronger as they adjust. Your hips a little wider and your ass and stomach more firm and small but perky breasts appear as you pull the suit up. Your arms thin out but like your legs gain a bit of muscle definition. Lastly your head and neck change and straight, brown hair that stops just short of your shoulders appears on your head.

"Whoa!" you state quietly as you catch sight of yourself. You flex an arm, run a hand over your breasts and stomach. Alexis' memories come pouring in. She goes to Saint Siena's Girls Academy, a private and very exclusive all-girls school for grades 6-12 where she's among the top percentile of her class academically in addition to being a gifted clarinet player. More importantly for her, however, is that she's also a gifted soccer player. That explains the strong legs and arms, the girl keeps herself in shape.

She's equally girly and a tomboy and a bit of a daddy's girl. Though her brother is the heir to the Van Lewen fortune, Alexis' father dotes on her seeing her as someone who will take the family far once she's a bit older. For all intents and purposes she's a modern day princess and treated as such and though she's spoiled she's not quite as haughty as someone in her position could be. And that's when another memory hits you, one that tells you your luck has paid off.

The Scarlet Bloom.

It's at the bank nearby, that much is true. However Marcus never had any intention to give the Scarlet Bloom back. The Vincents will eventually get a Scarlet Bloom back, it will just be a forgery, however, like the one currently in Bob Foxworth's pocket. No Marcus' real reason for getting it was simple: it was a gift for Alexis. It is kept in a vault at the bank though a secret one under, and accessible from, the "real" vault where most valuables are stored. And as it was Alexis' gift, she can go and see it any time she pleases. Something she likes to do once or twice a week.

You've hit the jackpot you realize as you slip on Alexis' underwear. All of this time you went from adult to adult and in the end it was a kid, one not much younger than yourself, that held the key to getting the Bloom. You slip the sleeveless black dress on, put on the dark pumps, the long black gloves, the pearl necklace, and the white headband to push your hair back. A cute girl, you regard yourself in the mirror, one who will blossom into something as beautiful as the jewel you can waltz in and take.

Marcus and Clarissa return. So does Daniel with lipstick smeared on him. You pack your things, you're leaving. The Van Lewen estate is close by but you wonder... should you ask for a quick detour to the bank to look at "your" jewel? You assume that asking would be enough, Daddy would do anything for his Princess, but things have been thrown into chaos. Perhaps he might be on edge and waiting a day or so would be the better option.
